aws::graph::propositions: # Pitts S-12 Aircraft Fuel System and Documentation Information
The POH found in the airplane was specific to the accident airplane by serial number.
The POH was prepared by an individual who is an airshow pilot who flies a Pitts S-12.
The POH document consisted of 21 single-sided pages.
The POH stated that the airplane had a total fuel capacity of 54 gallons.
The POH stated that 53 gallons of the total fuel capacity were usable.
The POH presented a table for five different engine power settings.
The engine power settings in the POH were Takeoff, Max Acro, Mid Acro, Normal Cruise, and Economy Cruise.
The POH power setting table included RPM, manifold pressure, and fuel flow values.
The POH did not define applicable conditions such as altitude or temperature for the power settings.
The POH power setting table stated it was for a "M-14P(PF) Engine and MTV-9-C/CL250(260)-29 propeller."
The POH table stated that takeoff power was 400hp.
The takeoff fuel burn rate was 46 gallons per hour according to the POH.
The normal cruise fuel burn rate was 16 gallons per hour according to the POH.
The economy cruise fuel burn rate was 14 gallons per hour according to the POH.
The POH "Procedures" section did not contain information regarding fuel management.
The POH contained a seven-step checklist for "Inflight Engine Restart."
The "Inflight Engine Restart" checklist included a step for glide speed of "100 MPH."
The "Inflight Engine Restart" checklist included a step for throttle setting of "OPEN 1/4 FULL."
The "Inflight Engine Restart" checklist included a step for boost pump to be "ON."
The "Inflight Engine Restart" checklist did not cite a specific fuel tank selection.
The "Inflight Engine Restart" checklist did not contain any reference to the engine primer switch.
The engine in the airplane was a "VMP" brand.
The engine model was M14P.
The engine serial number was K?012068.
The engine serial number appeared to match the engine data plate.
The propeller was an "MT" brand.
The propeller model was MTV-9-K-C/CL250-29.
The airplane was equipped with three fuel tanks.
The three fuel tanks were a wing-mounted auxiliary tank, a fuselage-mounted main tank, and a fuselage-mounted header tank.
The main tank was plumbed directly to the header tank.
The header tank was plumbed to the fuel selector valve.
The header tank was plumbed to the engine.
The auxiliary tank was plumbed directly to the fuel selector valve.

text:
# ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

## Pilots Operating Handbook (POH) Information

A POH was found in the airplane. The POH cover page indicated that it was specific to the accident airplane by serial number, and was prepared by an individual whose website indicated that he is an airshow pilot who flies a Pitts S-12. The document consisted of 21 single-sided pages. The POH stated that the airplane had a total fuel capacity of 54 gallons, of which 53 gallons were usable.

The POH presented a table for five different engine power settings (Takeoff, Max Acro, Mid Acro, Normal Cruise, and Economy Cruise) with accompanying RPM, manifold pressure, and fuel flow values. The POH did not define any other applicable conditions such as altitude or temperature. The POH power setting table stated that it was for a "M-14P(PF) Engine and MTV-9-C/CL250(260)-29 propeller." The POH table stated that takeoff power was 400hp. The takeoff, normal cruise, and economy cruise fuel burn rates were 46, 16, and 14 gph respectively.

The POH "Procedures" section did not contain any information regarding fuel management, but did contain a seven-step checklist for "Inflight Engine Restart." That checklist included steps regarding glide speed ("100 MPH"), throttle setting ("OPEN 1/4 FULL"), and boost pump ("ON"). The checklist did not cite a specific fuel tank selection, or contain any reference to the engine primer switch.

## Engine and Propeller Information

According to the engine logbook, the engine was a "VMP," model M14P, serial number K?012068; which appeared to match the engine data plate. According to the propeller logbook, the propeller was an "MT" brand, and cited as a model MTV-9-K-C/CL250-29.

## Airplane Fuel System

The airplane was equipped with three fuel tanks; a wing-mounted auxiliary ("aux") tank, and fuselage-mounted main and header tanks. The main tank was plumbed directly to the header tank, which in turn was plumbed to the fuel selector valve and then to the engine. The aux tank was plumbed directly to the fuel selector valve.
